title: R41131
content: The alternate engine program for the F-35 Lightning II fighter was a significant issue for Congress in FY2012, with implications for the defense budget and military capability. The program developed the General Electric/Rolls-Royce F136 engine as an alternative to the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine. Congress rejected proposals to terminate the program in previous budgets. In FY2011, the Administration's budget proposed to terminate the alternate engine program for the F-35 fighter. Congress eliminated funding for the program, leading to the end of the F136 engine development by General Electric and Rolls-Royce. The Department of Defense selected the Lockheed Martin F-35 with the Pratt & Whitney F135 engine as the winner of the JSF competition in 2001. DOD plans to purchase 2,456 JSFs for the Air Force, Navy, and Marine Corps. In FY1996, Congress mandated the development of an alternate engine for the F-35, resulting in the creation of the F136 engine by General Electric and Rolls-Royce. The F135 and F136 engines were designed to be interchangeable without modifying the F-35 airframe. Despite initial attempts to terminate the alternate engine program in FY2007, Congress restored funding due to potential cost savings from competition. The alternate engine program for the F-35 was terminated by DOD in 2011 after Congress rejected funding for it. Supporters of the termination argued that developing a second engine would significantly increase costs for the F-35 program. The F-35 program office stated that a cost increase due to production economies of scale would reduce the number of F-35s that could be procured, potentially leading to cuts in future capabilities and force structure. Procuring a second engine would increase F-35 life-cycle operation and support costs, posing challenges for maintenance on aircraft carriers. Having a second engine is deemed unnecessary to sustain international interest in the F-35. The F-35 program does not require a second engine to maintain international interest, as key buyers are already committed due to the aircraft's capabilities and cost. Congress accepts the risk of using single designs across fleets, including powerplants and airframes. While there is a risk of fleet grounding with a single airframe design, this is a known issue that has been managed in the past. The F-35 program does not need a backup engine as risks of fleet grounding are acceptable to Congress and DOD. Development of the F135 engine has progressed enough to not require an alternate engine program. Fixes for past test failures have been identified and implemented. Opponents argue that terminating the alternate engine program does not comply with FY2008 defense regulations. Terminating the alternate engine program for the Joint Strike Fighter does not comply with FY2008 defense regulations requiring the development and procurement of 2 propulsion system options. The development and competitive production of a second engine for the Joint Strike Fighter (F-35) is essential to avoid grounding the entire fleet in case of engine problems. Having a second engine option would allow for competition in procurement and support, potentially reducing costs compared to a sole-source procurement. Having a second engine for the F-35 is crucial to avoid fleet grounding in case of engine issues. Competition in procurement and support can reduce costs compared to sole-source procurement. It would also lead to better engine performance, increased reliability, and improved contractor responsiveness. Two production lines would allow for quicker production surges and maintain competition in future tactical aircraft engine development. The F-35 program could benefit from having a second engine in production to sustain international interest and maximize exports.
